emphasized the modern Greeks' ancient heritage

qas.question: What became the official dialect of Greeks and what was it missing ?

answers.text: Katharevousa, a somewhat artificial form of Greek purged of all foreign influence and words, as the official language of the Greek state.

qas.question: What other dialects share a thread with the French language?
What non-radical political changes occurred during the 19th century?

plausible_answers.text: emphasized the modern Greeks' ancient heritage

qas.question: What did these changes not highlight?
What became the official dialect of Greeks and what was it not missing?

context: Greek demonstrates several linguistic features that are shared with <a0_0>other <b5_0>Balkan languages<b5_0/>, such as Albanian, Bulgarian and Eastern Romance languages (see Balkan sprachbund),<a0_0/> and has absorbed many foreign words, primarily of Western European and Turkish origin. Because of <a1_0>the movements of <b6_0>Philhellenism and the Diafotismos<b6_0/> in the 19th century<a1_0/>, which <a2_0><b7_0>emphasized the modern Greeks' ancient heritage<b7_0/><a2_0/>, these foreign influences were excluded from official use via the creation of <a3_0><b8_0>Katharevousa<b8_0/>, a somewhat artificial form of Greek purged of all foreign influence and words, as the official language of the Greek state.<a3_0/> <a4_0>In 1976, however, the Hellenic Parliament voted to make the spoken Dimotiki the official language<a4_0/>, making Katharevousa obsolete.
